choices.text: Nothing, as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Ajay, a 3-year-old child, is the younger brother of Anuj, who is currently undergoing treatment for diphtheria in the hospital. Ajay lives in the same household and received his diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago. What is the most appropriate course of action for the care of Ajay?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ajay is a household contact of a diphtheria case and should receive erythromycin prophylaxis, even though he is vaccinated and asymptomatic.

  • When a confirmed case of diphtheria is identified, close contacts (like household members) are at risk of asymptomatic carriage or developing the disease.
  • Recommended Management for Asymptomatic Close Contacts (like Ajay):
    • Antibiotic Prophylaxis:
      • Oral erythromycin 40-50 mg/kg/day (max 2 g/day) for 10 days
      • OR single dose of benzathine penicillin G
    • Vaccination Review:
      • Booster only if:
      • Less than 3 doses taken previously
      • No booster in the last 5 years
      • Ajay received his last diphtheria vaccine dose 16 months ago, so he does not need a booster now.
    • Monitoring:
      • Observe for symptoms for 7 days
      • Take cultures if symptoms develop

Explanation of other options:

One booster dose (Option A): Not needed now, as Ajay received a dose within the last 5 years. Boosters are only required if the last dose was ≥5 years ago.

Nothing, as the child is already exposed (Option B): Incorrect, because vaccination does not guarantee full protection, and exposed individuals can still become carriers or symptomatic.

Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid (Option C): Not indicated in Ajay's case, as diphtheria toxoid is only added if: Immunization is incomplete or last booster was ≥5 years ago

questions.text: Which neonatal anomaly is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exstrophy bladder is a congenital anomaly where the bladder mucosa is exposed outside the abdominal wall due to failure of mesodermal migration.

  • Bladder exstrophy results from a failure of mesoderm to migrate and form the lower abdominal wall, leading to a defect through which the posterior bladder wall protrudes and is visible externally.
  • It typically presents in neonates with the bladder mucosa exposed, downwardly displaced umbilicus, widely separated pubic symphysis, and epispadias.
  • In males, dorsal chordee and shortened penis are seen.
  • In females, there is bifid clitoris and wide labial separation.
  • If left untreated, patients suffer from complete urinary incontinence and are at increased risk for bladder adenocarcinoma.
  • This condition is easily distinguishable from other anterior abdominal wall defects due to visible bladder mucosa, absence of a herniated bowel sac, and association with genital anomalies.

Explanation of other options:

Omphalocele (Option A): Presents as herniation of abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a translucent sac. The umbilical cord inserts into the sac-not seen in exstrophy.

Gastroschisis (Option B): Abdominal wall defect lateral to the umbilicus, with free-floating bowel loops that lack a covering sac-distinct from bladder mucosa exposure.

Patent vitello intestinal duct (Option C): Persistent communication between the intestine and umbilicus, may present as a fistula, sinus, or cyst near the umbilicus-does not show an exposed bladder.

choices.text: Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are positive and used as a screening test
A type of food allergy causing skin rashes
A genetic disorder leading to lactose intolerance
An infection in the gastrointestinal tract caused by bacteria

questions.text: What is Celiac Sprue in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder screened by detecting anti-tTG antibodies, especially in children presenting with gluten sensitivity symptoms.

  • Celiac sprue, or celiac disease, is a chronic autoimmune disorder triggered by ingestion of gluten (found in wheat, barley, rye)
  • It primarily affects the small intestine, leading to villous atrophy, malabsorption, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and growth failure in children.
  • The first-line screening test is the detection of anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) IgA antibodies, which are highly sensitive and specific for celiac disease.
  • If the antibody test is positive, it is typically followed by upper GI endoscopy with duodenal biopsy, which reveals:
    • Villous atrophy
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Intraepithelial lymphocytosis
  • Other relevant antibodies include:
    • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA)
    • Anti-gliadin antibodies (AGA) - less commonly used now
  • Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2/DQ8 genes and can also lead to secondary lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage.

Explanation of other options:

A type of food allergy causing skin rashes (Option B): Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition, not a classical IgE-mediated food allergy, although it may present with dermatitis herpetiformis, a blistering skin condition.

A genetic disorder leading to lactose intolerance (Option C): While celiac disease is genetic, it does not primarily cause lactose intolerance. However, lactose intolerance may occur secondarily due to villus damage impairing lactase enzyme activity.

An infection in the gastrointestinal tract caused by bacteria (Option D): Celiac disease is not an infectious disease; it is a non-infectious immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

choices.text: Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency
Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency
Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency

questions.text: An infant presents with vomiting after feeding. A Benedict's test is performed and returns positive for a non-glucose reducing substance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A positive Benedict's test with vomiting after milk feeding in a neonate indicates classic galactosemia, due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase deficiency.

  • Classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT).
  • This leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactose in the blood and tissues after ingestion of lactose (milk sugar).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset after milk feeding (contains lactose → galactose)
    • Vomiting
    • Diarrhea
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Failure to thrive
    • Cataracts
    • Intellectual disability if untreated
    • Reducing substances (e.g., galactose) in urine → positive Benedict's test
  • Investigations:
    • Positive Benedict's test (detects reducing sugars, including galactose)
    • Enzyme assay for GALT activity
    • Confirmed by genetic testing
  • Management:
    • Eliminate galactose/lactose from diet (soy-based formula)
    • Early diagnosis prevents irreversible complications

Explanation of other options:

Hereditary fructose intolerance (Option B): Caused by aldolase B deficiency, presenting after fructose/sucrose ingestion (usually post-weaning), not soon after milk feeding. Benedict's test may be positive for fructose, but timing of symptoms doesn't match.

G6PD deficiency (Option C): Leads to hemolysis, especially after oxidative stress (e.g., infection, fava beans, certain drugs). No vomiting after feeding or positive Benedict's test expected.

Galactokinase deficiency (Option D): A milder form of galactosemia presenting primarily with cataracts, without systemic symptoms like vomiting or hepatomegaly. Benedict's test may still be positive, but not as severe as GALT deficiency.

questions.text: At what age is surgery typically performed for cleft lip in infants?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cleft lip repair is typically performed at around 3 months of age, following the "Rule of 10s" to ensure optimal safety and outcomes.

  • Cleft lip is a congenital craniofacial anomaly where there is a failure of fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes.
  • Timing of Surgical Repair:
    • The widely followed guideline for cleft lip repair is the "Rule of 10s":
      • 10 weeks of age
      • 10 pounds (approximately 4.5 kg)
      • 10 g/dL hemoglobin
    • This rule ensures the infant has:
      • Sufficient growth and development
      • Adequate nutritional reserves
      • Improved anesthesia safety
    • Early correction helps with:
      • Feeding efficiency
      • Speech development
      • Parent-infant bonding
      • Cosmetic and psychological benefit

Explanation of other options:

6 months (Option B): More appropriate for cleft palate repair, not cleft lip. Delaying lip repair till 6 months may impact early feeding and bonding.

1 year (Option C): Typically the age for cleft palate repair to support speech development, but too late for primary cleft lip repair.

18 months (Option D): Significantly delayed for cleft lip repair. At this age, speech development is well underway, and late repair may impair outcomes.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with stable vitals and an ECG showing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a hemodynamically stable child with PSVT, the first-line treatment is IV adenosine at an initial dose of 0.1 mg/kg.

  • Paroxysmal supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT) is a common pediatric arrhythmia characterized by a sudden onset of narrow complex tachycardia.
  • In children with stable hemodynamics, adenosine is the drug of choice due to its short half-life and effectiveness in blocking AV nodal conduction, thereby terminating the reentrant circuit.
  • The initial dose of adenosine is 0.1 mg/kg IV as a rapid bolus.
  • If ineffective, the dose can be increased to 0.2 mg/kg.
  • It must be followed by a saline flush and should be given via a central line or proximal IV for maximal effect.
  • The drug works by causing transient AV block, which often restores sinus rhythm in AVNRT or AVRT.
  • Before adenosine, vagal maneuvers (like Valsalva or ice pack to the face in infants) are attempted.
  • ECG findings in PSVT:
    • Regular rhythm
    • Narrow QRS complexes (<120 ms)
    • P waves often not visible or retrograde
    • HR: 180-250 bpm in children

Fig: Typical AVNRT terminated by carotid sinus massage

Explanation of other options:

Cardioversion (Option A): Used in hemodynamically unstable PSVT or when adenosine fails. This child is stable, so it's not first-line.

Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg (Option B): This is the second-line dose used if 0.1 mg/kg fails. Not appropriate as the initial dose.

IV Adrenaline (Option D): Not indicated in PSVT. Adrenaline is reserved for cardiac arrest (asystole, PEA) or anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bochdalek hernia, a posterolateral diaphragmatic defect, is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), typically occurring on the left side.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a developmental defect of the diaphragm that allows abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development (pulmonary hypoplasia).
  • Bochdalek Hernia - Key Features:
    • Location: Posterolateral diaphragm (usually left-sided)
    • Cause: Failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure during embryogenesis
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • Respiratory distress in the neonatal period
      • Scaphoid abdomen (due to displaced abdominal contents)
      • Decreased breath sounds on the affected side
      • Mediastinal shift on imaging
    • Diagnosis: Antenatal ultrasound or postnatal chest X-ray
    • Management: Initial stabilization with ventilation, followed by surgical repair

Explanation of other options:

Hiatal Hernia (Option A): Involves stomach herniation through the esophageal hiatus. Typically acquired in adults, not a common form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Morgagni Hernia (Option B): Anterior diaphragmatic defect through the foramen of Morgagni. It is less common and often asymptomatic or incidentally found.

Umbilical Hernia (Option D): Protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring, common in infants, but not a type of diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: At which of the following ages does maximum brain growth occur?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maximum brain growth occurs during the first year of life, with the brain reaching approximately 60% of its adult size by 1 year.

  • The first year of life is the most critical period for brain development, both in terms of volume expansion and neural connectivity.
  • During this time:
    • The brain increases rapidly in weight and size.
    • Synaptogenesis, dendritic growth, and myelination accelerate.
    • The anterior fontanelle remains open to accommodate this rapid growth.
  • Brain growth milestones:
    • At birth: Brain is ~25% of adult size.
    • At 1 year: ~60% of adult size.
    • At 2 years: ~75% of adult size.
    • At 3 years: ~80-85% of adult size.
    • At 4 years: ~90% of adult size.
    • By 6-7 years: Nearly 95% of adult brain volume is achieved.
  • Despite early structural development, functional maturation (e.g., cognition, language, memory) continues through adolescence.

Explanation of other options:

2 years (Option B): The brain reaches ~75% of adult size, but the peak growth rate has already passed.

3 years (Option C): The brain is ~80-85% of adult size. Growth is ongoing but significantly slower.

4 years (Option D): Brain is ~90% of adult size. Most of the structural growth is completed, but functional development persists.

questions.text: A floppy infant presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pompe disease presents in infancy with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly, due to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes affecting cardiac and skeletal muscle.

  • Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency.
  • This leads to accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, especially in the cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • Clinical Features of Infantile Pompe Disease:
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Macroglossia
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy → Cardiomegaly on X-ray
    • Feeding difficulties
    • Respiratory distress
  • Investigations:
    • Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly
    • Elevated CK, AST, ALT
    • ECG: Short PR interval, tall QRS
    • PAS-positive vacuoles in muscle biopsy
    • Confirmatory test: Enzyme assay showing low acid α-glucosidase
  • Management:
    • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) - Alglucosidase alfa
    • Supportive care (nutrition, respiratory)

Explanation of other options:

Transposition of the Great Arteries (Option B): Presents with cyanosis early in life. While cardiomegaly may be seen, hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not typical features.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option C): Causes cyanosis and a boot-shaped heart on X-ray. It does not present with generalized hypotonia or hepatomegaly.

Ebstein's anomaly (Option D): Involves downward displacement of tricuspid valve, presenting with cyanosis and right-sided heart failure. Hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not characteristic.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with fever, rash, bleeding gums, and a positive tourniquet test. His platelet count is 25,000/mm³. Which of the following is the most important prognostic feature in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a suspected case of dengue hemorrhagic fever, platelet count is the most important prognostic indicator, directly correlating with bleeding risk.

  • This clinical presentation; fever, rash, bleeding gums, positive tourniquet test, and thrombocytopenia (25,000); is strongly suggestive of Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) or Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP).
  • In such settings, platelet count is a critical parameter used to monitor the severity of thrombocytopenia and to guide risk of bleeding and decisions like hospitalization or platelet transfusion.
  • Key prognostic roles of platelet count in Dengue:
    • Risk of spontaneous bleeding increases sharply when platelet count falls below 20,000/mm³.
    • Helps classify severity and need for inpatient management.
    • Guides decisions on fluid resuscitation and platelet support.

Explanation

Elevated total leukocyte count (Option B): May indicate secondary infection but is not a key prognostic marker in bleeding complications of dengue or ITP.

Hematocrit (Option C): In dengue shock syndrome, hematocrit helps assess plasma leakage, but bleeding risk is more directly related to platelet count.

Peripheral smear (Option D): Useful for identifying morphological changes or ruling out leukemias or infections, but not prognostic in acute bleeding risk management.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 50,000 cells/cu.mm, and petechiae and purpura. What is the recommended drug treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vincristine + Prednisolone is the standard induction regimen for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the most likely diagnosis in this child.

  • The child presents with anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, hepatosplenomegaly, and petechiae, which are classic features of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)-the most common leukemia in children.
  • Initial treatment (induction phase) for ALL aims to achieve complete remission and involves:
    • Vincristine (microtubule inhibitor, halts cell division)
    • Prednisolone (a glucocorticoid, induces apoptosis in lymphoblasts)
  • These agents form the backbone of initial therapy, especially in low-risk or standard-risk ALL.
  • Phases of ALL treatment:
    • Induction therapy: Vincristine + Prednisolone (± L-asparaginase, daunorubicin based on risk stratification)
    • Consolidation: To eliminate residual disease and CNS-directed therapy
    • Maintenance therapy: To prevent relapse using methotrexate, 6-MP, etc.
    • Supportive care: Includes acyclovir for viral prophylaxis and cotrimoxazole for pneumocystis prophylaxis.

Explanation of other options:

IVIG (Option B): Used in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), not in leukemia. It reduces immune-mediated platelet destruction but doesn't treat leukemic cell proliferation.

L-Asparaginase + Prednisolone (Option C): While this combination is also used in ALL therapy, it typically forms part of expanded induction or consolidation phases. Vincristine + Prednisolone is more appropriate for initial induction.

Daunorubicin + Prednisolone (Option D): This combination is more commonly used in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). In ALL, daunorubicin is reserved for high-risk or poor prognosis subtypes.

questions.text: An infant presents with recurrent chest infections and tachypnea. Identify the likely clinical condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CCAM presents in infancy with recurrent respiratory infections and tachypnea due to malformed cystic lung tissue.

  • Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (CCAM), now known as Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM), is a rare developmental malformation where hamartomatous lung tissue forms cysts, typically limited to a single lobe.
  • These cysts impair normal lung function, leading to symptoms such as tachypnea, recurrent chest infections, and respiratory distress, even in early infancy.
  • On chest X-ray: Multicystic mass, often with mediastinal shift.
  • Diagnosed prenatally or postnatally with imaging (X-ray/CT).
  • Management: Surgical resection-often done before 1 year due to risk of malignant transformation (e.g., pleuropulmonary blastoma).
  • Pathogenesis: Embryological injury before the 35th day of gestation disrupts bronchopulmonary development.

Explanation of other options:

Right-sided Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (Option B): Presents with severe respiratory distress immediately after birth, not recurrent infections. Bowel loops in the chest may shift mediastinum. Not typically associated with chronic recurrent chest infections in infancy.

Congenital Lobar Emphysema (Option C): Causes overinflation of a pulmonary lobe, leading to compression of adjacent structures and acute respiratory distress, usually at birth or within a few days. Recurrent infections are not a hallmark feature.

Cystic Fibrosis (Option D): Can cause chronic lung infections, but usually presents with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, clubbing, and positive sweat chloride test. Onset is typically later and more systemic in presentation.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6709284/

questions.text: A child presents with generalized body aches, poor wound healing, corkscrew hairs on her arms, and white lines of Frenkel on X-ray as shown below. This clinical presentation is most consistent with which of the following micronutrient deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) leads to defective collagen synthesis, resulting in fragile capillaries, bleeding, poor wound healing, corkscrew hairs, and characteristic radiological findings like white lines of Frenkel.

  • Vitamin C plays a crucial role in collagen synthesis, which is essential for maintaining the structural integrity of blood vessels, skin, bone, and connective tissues.
  • Scurvy occurs when there is prolonged deficiency of vitamin C, especially in children with inadequate dietary intake (e.g., lack of fruits and vegetables).
  • Clinical Features of Scurvy:
    • Musculoskeletal pain, particularly in legs
    • Corkscrew hairs, petechiae, ecchymoses
    • Poor wound healing, bleeding gums, anemia
    • Pseudoparalysis: refusal to move limbs due to pain
    • Frog-leg posture
    • Scorbutic rosary at the costochondral junctions
    • White lines of Frenkel (dense metaphyseal lines seen on X-ray)
    • Pelkan spurs: metaphyseal spurs
  • Radiological Signs:
    • White line of Frenkel: dense zone of provisional calcification
    • Wimberger ring: circular calcification surrounding the epiphysis
    • Scorbutic rosary: sharply defined, angular swellings at the costochondral junctions (unlike the smoother swellings in rickets)
  • Treatment:
    • Vitamin C supplementation (100-200 mg/day)
    • Symptom resolution typically begins within 1 week

Explanation of other options:

Zinc deficiency (Option A): Causes growth retardation, alopecia, delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, and dermatitis, but not corkscrew hairs or Frenkel lines.

Copper deficiency (Option C): Leads to anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmented hair, but not the bleeding or radiologic features seen in scurvy.

Iron deficiency (Option D): Presents with pallor, fatigue, irritability, and microcytic hypochromic anemia, but not corkscrew hairs, bleeding gums, or radiologic signs of scurvy.

questions.text: A child presents with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy shows a characteristic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of macrophages. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gaucher disease, caused by glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leads to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages, giving the classic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on bone marrow biopsy.

  • Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • It is caused by deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase), leading to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages.
  • Key Features of Gaucher Disease:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly (due to infiltration by Gaucher cells)
    • Pancytopenia or anemia
    • Bone pain, osteopenia, avascular necrosis
    • Neurological involvement in some types (especially Type 2 and Type 3
    • Characteristic Gaucher cells: lipid-laden macrophages with "crumpled tissue paper" cytoplasm in bone marrow biopsy
  • Types of Gaucher Disease:
    • Type 1 (non-neuronopathic): Most common, affects spleen, liver, bone
    • Type 2 (acute neuronopathic): Infantile onset, severe neurological symptoms
    • Type 3 (chronic neuronopathic): Slower neurological progression
  • Treatment:
    • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with recombinant glucocerebrosidase
    • Substrate reduction therapy (SRT) in select cases

Explanation of other options:

Hexosaminidase-A (Option A): Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, cherry-red macula, and no hepatosplenomegaly or "crumpled tissue paper" cells.

Iduronate 2-sulphatase (Option B): Deficiency causes Hunter syndrome (MPS II), a mucopolysaccharidosis presenting with coarse facial features, developmental delay, and hepatosplenomegaly, but not the marrow findings seen in Gaucher disease.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (Option C): Deficiency causes G6PD deficiency, a hemolytic anemia triggered by oxidative stress (e.g., infections, fava beans), with no bone involvement or Gaucher cells.

questions.text: A child presents with malnutrition and multiple follicular, dry papules on the elbows and knees. Improvement of the skin lesions is observed following vitamin supplementation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phrynoderma is a follicular hyperkeratotic disorder associated with multiple vitamin deficiencies, especially vitamin A, and improves with vitamin supplementation.

  • Phrynoderma, also known as toad skin, is a condition characterized by dry, horny follicular papules distributed commonly on extensor surfaces like elbows, knees, buttocks, and thighs.
  • It is seen in malnourished individuals, particularly children, and is attributed to multiple nutritional deficiencies, especially:
    • Vitamin A
    • Vitamin C, Vitamin E,
    • B-complex vitamins, and
    • Essential fatty acids
  • The papules are due to follicular plugging and hyperkeratosis, giving the skin a rough texture.
  • The hallmark of the diagnosis is improvement of the lesions with vitamin and nutritional supplementation.

Explanation of other options:

Keratosis Pilaris (Option B): Though also present with follicular papules, it is a genetic condition unrelated to malnutrition or vitamin deficiency, and typically does not improve with vitamin supplementation.

Darier Disease (Option C): A genetic disorder of keratinization presenting with greasy, warty papules in seborrheic areas (chest, back, forehead); not related to malnutrition and does not improve with vitamins.

Lichen Planus (Option D): An autoimmune inflammatory condition with flat-topped, violaceous, itchy papules, often involving wrists and oral mucosa-does not resemble follicular papules or respond to vitamin therapy.

questions.text: A child presents with photosensitivity and multiple skin cancers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair leading to photosensitivity and early-onset skin cancers.

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in nucleotide excision repair mechanisms, specifically the inability to repair UV-induced thymidine dimers in DNA.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Severe sunburn with minimal UV exposure
    • Photosensitivity
    • Freckling and hyperpigmented macules in sun-exposed areas
    • Development of multiple skin malignancies (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma) at an early age
    • Ocular involvement and neurological degeneration in some cases
  • The hallmark is early and multiple cutaneous malignancies, especially in sun-exposed regions.

Explanation of other options:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): A genetic disorder of collagen type I causing bone fragility, blue sclerae, and fractures. Photosensitivity or skin cancer is not a feature.

Hypervitaminosis A (Option C): Causes dry skin, alopecia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pseudotumor cerebri, but not skin cancer or DNA repair defects.

Paget's disease (Option D): A disorder of abnormal bone remodeling, usually in elderly individuals. It does not affect children or cause skin cancers.
